pros: Everyone in the org is mission driven, not product driven or racing the corporate ladder for a title. These wild 1-star reviews are likely not National employees or are disgruntled former employees that were let go from performance issues. It's a non-profit, of course the salaries are not great, that shouldn't be a shock to anyone in the NP world. Everything the Recruiter for the National Office told me has been the truth and I love my job and the people we work with across the departments. From the C-Suite down, we have some phenomenal people working here doing great work. The org has made huge strides since going remote in hiring great talent across the country and some phenomenal diverse hires that have been rare in the non-profit world, the teams have been adding such amazing people that are great to work with.
cons: Obviously pay is tough and non-profits can't meet market averages, that's a no brainer. Everyone wants to make as much money as they can but be realistic. Camera on meetings get old, quick. Let's get back to camera optional.

review_title: Believe the Bad Reviews - Sad but true
pros: The mission. The wish kids. Some nice people. That’s it.
cons: Believe the bad reviews. All of them. (The dismissive attitude toward them is a perfect example of a narcissistic org: “We refuse to improve. I’m not the problem, you’re the problem.”) Incompetent, over-paid leadership: National Office politics and National/Chapter infighting perpetually delay progress. Expect your projects to take 3x as long. Misalignment & poor communication = confusion & low morale. They can’t handle a remote culture. Expect more turnover. It’s not disgruntled or low-performing employees who leave, it’s people who love the mission, but believe the org should live up to its values. And the gossip mill: Wow! Be ready to pull knives out of your back daily.

pros: The cause is great - it is wonderful to see wishes improving sick children's lives
cons: Management says that they are a casual team that is open to change but responds poorly to suggested changes. CEO holds complete power over decisions and does not allow others to disagree. Gossip and pettiness are commonplace. Marketing mix is heavily weighted towards traditional marketing with no evidence that this is working. Digital marketing is given less than 5% of marketing budget. The CEO takes a 6 figure salary, even though the annual funds raised are less than 2 million.

review_title: This Rating Reflects the Current State of this Chapter, not the Whole Job
job_title: Senior Manager of Marketing & Communication in Sacramento, CA
pros: This review is for Make-A-Wish Northeastern & Central California and Northern Nevada specifically. The mission and impact is tangible. This is one job where you can SEE and FEEL the impact you will be making. The work is very rewarding, and fun. Our kids wish for cool stuff! Whether it be a kiddo who wanted to be a trash collector, a delivery driver or a pop star, we get to work with some amazing kids who are so creative in what the wish for. Plus, many of the individuals who comprise the team are amazing. They care, and they work hard. For nearly all of four years working there, it's one of the most collaborative experiences I've had in my career with smart, talented and creative people. One of my absolute favorite things about this job was their investment in production equipment. With a Sony FX3, your videos will be top notch and they invested in a print quality printer, large format printer and cutting machine, giving you the opportunity to take a collateral piece from design to production. Working with the Brand and Marketing Team at Make-A-Wish America is amazing. There are some really great individuals working on that team who are always there to help if they can and to amplify the stories coming out of the chapter.
cons: Again, this review is for Make-A-Wish Northeastern & Central California and Northern Nevada specifically. For three+ years and throughout the pandemic, there really wasn't a lot that was wrong. I would say over the course of that time, our DEI initiatives were lacking. However, since really Spring 2022, the chapter has been in a state of flux. It has made growth opportunities harder to picture. Where it used to be senior leadership would have these conversations with their employees, that conversation for me was pushed back every few months with a promise to revisit the conversation that never came to fruition. So at present, growth in salary and role is stagnant to non-existant. But the main problem lie in the current CEO. They have a large ego, taking up an entire staff meeting to talk about themselves. At that same staff meeting a major announcement was made in the final five minutes which was an awful way to communicate changes that would affect colleagues and the chapter at large. The CEO's communication style is very apathetic as well. They aren't super interested in working with wish families during a wish (would rather talk to city dignitaries) and isn't particularly charismatic, which has resulted in poor performances at large fundraising events and even the loss of a few influential donors. More than anything, through a conversation I had directly with this individual, I don't believe they understand what the mission of Make-A-Wish is. It was the final red flag for me before I left and I did report to Make-A-Wish America which will hopefully mean it will be addressed. During my final week, I had a going away Zoom with my colleagues and it was so terribly nice to hear about the impact that my work has made on families across the chapter, and on my colleagues. Which is why it was very odd when the CEO walked past me without acknowledgement on my final day without saying good bye or thank you. Par for the course it would seem... Not convinced on the communication yet? Well know that benefits that were promised to us under the previous CEO, and the Interim CEO are being looked at under a fine toothed "cost cutting" microscope. Worse yet, the current CEO has cancelled some benefits without even announcing to the staff, including grief counseling, an amazing benefit that some were taking advantage of that was stripped from them without ANY communication. Embarrassing that one of my colleagues found out about this from the counselor and not the CEO who cancelled that benefit without any notice. It's either a lack of respect for the staff, or the CEO is so out of touch that she doesn't think about the staff at all when making decisions. I get a CEO's job is sometimes to make difficult decisions, but the lack of foresight and communication is exceptionally bad. As for Make-A-Wish America, the former CEO was incredible and we as individuals at the chapter heard from them often. Upon their retirement, his replacement, the Current Make-A-Wish America CEO, I'm not sure I've heard anything from them.

pros: The mission is the only pro. It’s impactful.
cons: As mentioned, please be mindful that if you are looking for a job at MAW, it is a federalized format with several individual chapters. This will make your job hunt more difficult, so focus on where the reviewer worked. My review is from a local chapter, not corporate. Here are my three top reasons I chose to leave: - Poor Leadership: I have never experienced such unprofessional and unkind management in my career. I’m not sure if it’s a lack of training, awareness, or truly just mean-spirited. Everyone was micromanaged, no matter your performance. No freedom for new ideas or projects. The few times I tried to share my concerns, I was brushed off. This poor leadership really effected my professional confidence in a way I never expected. - No HR Presence: Before I left, I did all I could to make things better. I documented poor situations I found myself in, and bravely addressed concerns I had with my boss directly and then worked up the leadership ladder from there. I didn’t have one ally in that office though, especially because there is no HR presence, so think of it as a small “mom and pop” shop. - Low Pay & Benefits: My first red flag should have been accepting the job knowing it was already below market value for a fundraiser of my tenure in our area. I counter-offered, and was told the board wouldn’t approve an increase. Should have run then. The low pay and poor benefits are not worth being a martyr for the mission.

review_title: Please, be aware of the negative reviews
pros: Wish families are incredible. They are faced with many struggled and yet are so grateful, even when their kids wish for something small.
cons: The turn over rate is so high because of employees being burned out, every fall you will see wish coordinators running away from the company. When many of us applied we all remember reading glassdoor reviews and seeing ones begging people to stay away from Make-A-Wish New Jersey. We disregarded thinking that it was one disgruntled employee. However, after our year of employment, many of us were leaving without any future job prospects.. thats how exhausted, mistreated and burned out we were. Please don't disregard the negative reviews. MAWNJ and many other chapters can get away with just letting their burned out employees leave because there is no HR presence in the building. They hire out HR and as a result there are no representatives of the company in the office. Those who are trusted to communicate with the HR company, don't in an honest way. They filter through the problems personally and determine if you are being honest enough to report it. Many people have tried to make reports, however almost none were successful. Those who were, went to the HR company directly, once upper management found out the employee was railed. Employees are yelled at, asked to work overtime for no overtime pay, and told to come into the office even when sick. It all stems from the top down and unfortunately change won't come to the NJ location until they stop avoiding accountability.

review_title: A feel-good organization you will work at for 1-3 years
pros: Nice mission, nice people. They invest in team building and training, and are very transparent with strategic plan and finances.
cons: Company can rely too heavily on the mission keeping employees around and not invest in lowering turnover. Salary is very low for everyone except directors, and employees are expected to work a lot of evenings and weekends. Too much administrative work that sucks up all your time and feels pointless. For example, reviews happen 2x per year and are 8-10 pages of essay questions. Then, very little opportunities for compensation increase unless you are there for a long time and are promoted to a new role. Most people don't stay very long, their turnover is too high.

Amazing name recognition for your resume.
cons:
No room to be creative, and consequently not much room for individual growth.  This particular office was not interested in hearing new ideas.  They're a bit disorganized and have a large physical-to-digital disconnect. 

Additionally, new management and corporate restructuring have created a high turnover culture. If you don't know how to perfectly interrupt what your supervisor is asking you to do then they will let you go. They may say they like questions, but if those questions question their method then you won't last long here. MAW knows plenty of people would work for them and they can fill your role quickly. 

Funding also isn't consistent for all roles.  Another note on funding: They accept funds from any and all donors no matter how problematic that donor may be with the rest of their money. Questionable media organizations , Multi-million dollar corporations etc. If you want to remain consistent in your values, don't work here.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Blue Bell, PA
pros: I loved working there. It was a pleasure coming to work and was eager to start my day. The employees were awesome and so supportive starting from day one!
cons: No cons. I loved my time there.

pros: Amazing work environment, great benefits and PTO, inspiring mission
cons: Nothing I can think of

pros: Great company culture was great
cons: There was no cons all

pros: Flexible schedule, amount of PTO
cons: Poor communication from leadership, low salaries

review_title: Great company, little growth or opportunity
pros: nice people and a nice mission
cons: low salary, not competitive, not much professional growth or additional opportunities

review_title: Great mission, great people, but limited opportunities for career growth
pros: Some outstanding colleagues who are generally very approachable. Incredible mission, opportunities to engage with and volunteer with the local chapter(s). Inexpensive healthcare, great, central location. CEO is outstanding: kind, genuine, caring, frugal and is invested in appropriately stewarding all constituents including staff, donors, volunteers, wish families and just people that are curious about the organization. He is very involved and takes a lot of time simply to thank people and sincerely learn about their interests, passions and motivations.
cons: Unfortunately, the CEO's leadership doesn't always trickle down and there are eternal power struggles, structural readjustments and maneuverings, some people in leadership roles that aren't really competent in their positions and manage their staff poorly. Compensation is average at best for the majority of staff (even in the non-profit sector) and there aren't career paths or opportunities for upward mobility. So many meetings for the sake of meetings and initiatives that distract from the mission of the organization. Many silos and cliques. Work is disproportionately distributed even amongst the same title grade.

review_title: Make A Wish of Metro New York and Western NY
pros:
- Wonderful cause. 
- Generally, a happy place to be.
cons:
- As much as management pretends to care about you both as an employee and an individual, they don’t. They don’t give you the tools you need to succeed in your position and then blame you for everything that’s going wrong. 
- Senior management has been at the organization long enough that they should realize a pattern, it’s not the people you’re hiring that can’t perform, it’s the illogical way you’re trying to run this organization.  
- HIGH turnover rate. About 10 people were fired/left this year alone. 
- No HR department. HR ‘rep’ is COO who is part of the problem and very friendly with people whom you would like to make complaints about. 
- Low pay and few vacation days/holidays. 
- Expect you to work a crazy amount of hours (evenings and weekends) to get to their goal of wishes.

job_title: Learning And Development Specialist in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Good people, fair salary, purposeful work
cons: not very diverse in stafff

review_title: Great Organisation helping a good cause
pros: People were very helpful and wanted the best for you. Would answer any questions or concerns. Good experience
cons: I did not encounter any

pros: Work in a life-changing environment
cons: Minimum wage job with little room to grow

pros: Wonderful mission that people care about
cons: People at Make-A-Wish America (the corporate headquarters) are really passionate about the mission, which is great. However, you would think feeling fulfilled in your career would make you happier as a human being. I have never met so many horribly mean, insensitive, angry, and stubborn people in my entire professional career. Upper management will make mistakes and then put the blame on lower level employees, constantly making the lower level employees feel horrible about things that were absolutely not their fault. If you are new to the organization, prepare to be stepped on over and over again. The people that have been at the organization for more than 5 years are basically a cult that rule the office and make everyone else miserable. The office atmosphere and culture is completely outdated and old fashioned. Prepare to follow rules that were made almost 40 years ago. There is so much red tape and absolute nonsense and nothing you can do to change any of it. Prepare to drown in red tape. It also follows the typical non-profit environment of not having enough resources. You will work overtime, work through your lunches, work weekends, and no one will thank you. Because every single person to forced to do it because every team is so understaffed.

review_title: The National Office is full of BS
pros: The mission is incredible and the local Chapters are amazing to work with.
cons: Extreme lack of diversity and inclusion, which is apparent by the employees they choose to highlight on the company page (majority female, white, millennial). Leadership at the National Office  are terrible and use the mission to hide behind poor decisions. They do not know how to engage employees or foster a positive working environment, which contributes to high turnover and low employee morale.  Majority of operational leadership at the National Office come from American Express and run it like a dysfunctional call center. You must play the political game & drink the koolaid to become a "favorite" if you want to receive development opportunities, be recognized for going above & beyond, or grow within the organization. If you don't play the political game, or if you decide to speak transparently about ongoing issues, you are completely excluded.

pros: Granting wishes of children with life-threatening illnesses
cons: Benefits, low salary, and volunteers

pros: There are so many wonderful things about working here. I have been here for over two years, now, and have progressed and developed like no other. I don't know what that comment "It's not what you think" is talking about because the majority of everyone here is anything BUT mean. That specific person must be mean themselves and perceive everything wrong because I have worked several places prior to here and have never met so many happy people who LOVE THEIR JOB! Just in the two years I've worked here they have taken the responses to the employee surveys and ACTUALLY DID SOMETHING ABOUT IT. They make changes when necessary and are open to new ideas, especially from the younger crowd. Please, don't let that one comment from one angry ex employee differ you. The benefits are wonderful. The work itself is fulfilling. The people are fantastic. I have never enjoyed my job before coming to MAW.
cons: There, of course, are some downsides to this job, but it's the typical office drama. There are a couple people who feed into it and I'm sure there are a couple managers who hold their employees down, but, FOR THE MOST PART, hard work is appreciated and acknowledged daily.

review_title: Great Mission, Poor Hiring Choices and Very Bad Management
pros:
I worked at Make A Wish Foundation of America full-time

Pros – The mission is the big driver here -- employees care about it and give their all. The organization has a great public image and is a champion fundraiser, but this covers up what goes on behind closed doors.
cons: Cons – The problem is with upper management -- there is considerable lack of distrust between employees and management. Upper management (not all direct supervisors) changed staff performance reviews without telling staff members. Staff are not treated well if you are not a favorite of the VP's. Staff are underpaid whereas management staff are taking home HUGE paychecks by comparison. Bonuses are provided based on favoritism, not performance. This is not an equitable work environment -- staff are very unhappy and there is a high turnover rate in the area of Development especically.

review_title: Great mission - but left a really bad taste in my mouth!
pros: MAWC has an amazing mission and it is run with wonderful volunteers.
cons: The payscale for positions are not equivalent to other similar charities in Canada.  New hires tend to be young and inexperienced and will be under-payed -- all with the promise of promotions in their near future.  Don't believe it --- promotions will take about 10 years to appear, and usually after a job that someone has left has been foisted on you (and they have not filled) AND with no title or pay raise.  People leave because they will never be promoted, mentored, or recognized for their contributions.  It's stagnant.

review_title: Hard NO on working for the National Office
pros: CEO communicates regularly to staff on upcoming events and status of the organization.
cons: CEO's lack of involvement with Executive Leadership Team and who is hired and who leaves has changed the National Office from a great place to work to a complete disaster. Some of the executive leaders are finally retiring but the national office has hired several unqualified and unprofessional Managers and Directors that rule by authority and create a stressful work environment. If job stability, advancement opportunities and friendly work environment are important to you, the National Office at Make A Wish would not be a good choice. It might sound good but after a few months, you will realize you made a huge mistake accepting a job working here.

review_title: The most poorly mismanaged organization you will ever work for! It is tragic.
pros: Great Mission,  amazing Wish kids and awesome  wish granters.
cons: The CEO, COO AND Program Director are all from an auditing or banking background with zero non profit experience.  Leadership is an oxymoron; a knee jerk reaction to whatever shows up on the radar that day, versus a thoughtful, well planned long term strategy. The CEO is an egotistical self absorbed fake. Senior leadership does not care about nor appreciate their people, mostly because they have no idea what people’s jobs actually are; secondarily, because they simply don’t care. They just care about protecting their very high salaries and bonuses ( which the CEO flaunts in front of lesser paid staff). This leadership team has created a toxic culture by letting the CEO run rampant, damaging relationships and angering new and longtime donors and supporters. The Board is naive and ineffective. All in all, it is a tragic situation and undeserved as Make-A-Wish is an amazing organization.

pros: They have a great mission but could accomplish more if they didn't overspend,
cons: Many but I'll list a few.  Horrible Directors and above. No job stability with very high turnover. Around 80% of their employees have been there less than 2 years and this is due to very poor leadership and no loyalty to their employees. They have terminated an entire department in a day leaving with no notice to the employees leaving ppl without jobs. I would not recommend working here. If you look at any of the job sites, MAW is always hiring and there is a reason for this. Again poor leadership and the buck stops with the CEO. David Williams has done a horrible job running the National Office. He is a nice guy in person but can not lead an organization.  Don't be fooled by the mission. If  career longevity and job stability is important to you, then this would not be a good career move.

job_title: National Office- Analyst/Specialist in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Free coffee, I guess. Benefits are fair. PTO is generous.
cons:
Oh where to begin.
Overworked and underpaid and highly patronizing. Everything is last minute. No one takes accountability. ESPESCIALLY not leadership. Top execs are rarely in the office and when they are they’re having personal meetings. 

For what the org does, you’d be amazed at how arrogant, selfish, lazy, and incompetent these people are and it is so engrained in the culture  Employee recognition is a joke- they’re grasping at straws to keep people at the org instead of actually listening to what leaving employees say. They make it look like they’re listening with “feedback” teams but nothing ever actually changes. 
They use something called kudos for employee recognition and it’s basically a popularity contest- the same handful of people get the monthly award.
Unless you’re a senior manager or above, they treat you as indispensable. There’s no appreciation for the work you do, and if it’s good work your supervisor will take credit for it.

review_title: Misery between 4 walls. Worst area is Compliance by far
pros: Great mission for those kids who are able to have wishes granted.
cons: Sadly, currently there are many dysfunctional areas within the National Office in Phoenix but I would say the most dysfunctional area to work in would be Compliance. They have been an internal department, outsourced, brought back in house and have changed directors all in only the past 5 years. I would say now unfortunately, its the worst it has been over the 5 years I've been with Make-A-Wish. I believe the reason for this is ineffective executive leadership and the CEO not being involved. If you are looking for job stability, i would highly recommend looking at other areas within the National Office as I don't predict it will get much better. Other areas definitely have their share of problems but nothing like Compliance. Good Luck !!!

review_title: CEO is in it for personal gain and doesn't care about the kids and wish families
pros: The mission is impressive and the Program Teams truly care about the wish children being served.
cons:
- The CEO (Siana Hunt) is only in it for personal gain
- She uses the corporate credit card like it is her own personal loan or ATM
- There are huge disparities not only in salary and benefits but also treatment of employees between the Wish granting staff vs. the Development staff
- the development staff makes more than twice as much as the program teams
-There are major compliance issues here but everyone looks the other way because of fear of losing their jobs and being slandered in the community
-The org loses 1-2 employees a month either by being fired, being pushed out due to ill treatment; The chapter turns over half of it's staff each year due to the CEO
-chapter was in an over $400K deficit for 2017!!

review_title: Wonderful culture to work in, feeling of unity and passion for the mission across all the departments
pros: Friendly people who are always willing to meet with you and talk about career possibilities no matter what position they are in, young lively office, you can tell everyone's heart is in the mission and go above and beyond to try to make the best experience for the children and families, the culture of the office is great! As an intern  you meet with the various directors so you get an overall understanding of how the foundation operates instead of just the specific department you are working in.
cons: Smaller office so not many job openings. As an intern the tasks they give can get repetitive, not much variation in what you get done and there is not much work with the families or children. Interns are only there for a semester so they turnover rate is pretty high in that aspect.

pros: I have found Make-A-Wish America to be the most rewarding work experience in my 13-year career. I work on a team that is passionate, focused, funny, and encouraging. To top it off, everything we do comes back to our mission of granting life-changing wishes for children with critical illnesses. I have had a pleasant experience with just about everyone I've collaborated with, and it feels like most people who have been here awhile are open to innovative change.  I am also trusted to work independently. It is an exciting time of change for the organization, which adds to the motivation of doing high-quality work.
cons: With Make-A-Wish being a nonprofit, some of the frills you might find elsewhere (more current software platforms, for example) are not here yet, but it sounds like upper management is genuinely open to hearing ideas of how we can do our jobs more efficiently to help achieve our mission.

pros: The mission is very motivating, however working there made me realize that I would much rather be a volunteer than spend my career there.
cons: There is a huge amount of turn-over at Make-A-Wish, and the reason is apparent once you have worked there for a couple months. They hire many individuals with what seems to be little care or thought at all. The Senior Leadership Team is also very elitist for working at such a small company. There needs to be a major overhaul in leadership (including with the CEO, who doesn't seem to have many new ideas or innovative suggestions for the future). They need to catch up with the millennial generation or they are going to fail.

pros: Knowing you work for an organization that grants wishes to sick children.
cons: I've worked for Make A Wish for many years and have seen it crumble in terms of poor executive leadership, loosing really good people and replacing them with people with bad attitudes and poor judgement which has led to overall very bad morale among the employees. Human Resources tries to show they are addressing the many problems within the national office but it's just a smoke screen. Very poor job stability and no long term growth. Some of the executive leadership team are finally retiring and the others were hired in from a credit care company.... There are too many disadvantages to working for the National Office that there is not enough space but areas to avoid are human resources, CFS,  anything job that involves finance or compliance I would highly recommend avoiding.

pros: Great mission, Great staff,  and great building
cons: The Senior management is out of control and has hired an additional senior management, who is just a puppet and a babysitter so he can not show up to work.  His fits of fury and criticism is intolerable.   He finally did something right and fired one of his senior managers of Mission but then as usually made a bad decision and promoted her mini me into that position.   The new managers has no people skills and is only concerned with saving her job.  She is cold, cruel and calculating.  She should have been fired with the former  VP.

pros: Incredible Mission and beginnings of the organization. Managers, coordinators, support staff and interns truly believe in Mission and work towards it.
cons: Low pay for all employees in a manager’s position or lower; chapter’s leadership team pretends to care about staff but little or no real recognition; high employee turnover with no efforts from anyone from the leadership team acknowledging nor making anything efforts to stop or minimize it; large gap in salaries between leadership and manager positions and below; no room for growth with zero opportunities for professional development or career growth. CEO and 1 or 1 members of leadership team attends yearly national conferences with no one else allowed.

review_title: Those that work in our organization share a deep-rooted passion for our mission which is to make wishes come true.
pros:
1. Passion of our fellow employees to our mission
2. Seeing the joy of the children we serve when their wishes come true
3. Commitment by our management to improve our efficiency and our ability to grant even more wishes
cons: Despite the great work we do, it's heartbreaking when we hear about wish kids who pass on. Although some wish kids are able to fully realize full, adult lives. Some don't.

pros: Amazing organization. Mission is wonderful. Not all chapters are alike - some smaller, some larger.
cons: Larger chapters lose sight of the mission and focus on numbers instead, resulting in a lesser-quality wish. Certain departments are understaffed,  "stepford-like," and micro-managed. Pay is insultingly low given weight of caseloads.High turnover rate.

pros: Some of the most kindhearted entry level staff and volunteers I have ever had the pleasure of knowing. The mission is worthy of good leadership.
cons: Employee moral is crazy low. The rate of turnover is so incredibly high - even middle managers don't last because they see the dysfunction of the leadership team. HR is a total joke - to the point of basically breaking the law with information shared with other employees. The CEO? Give me a break. Absolutely NO experience leading a multi-million dollar organization. Her idea of professional development and coaching is 'Be grateful and read Brene Brown books."  The decision-making model is completely lost on this group of managers. What should take 6 weeks takes 6 months. Everyone is afraid to speak their minds because of fear. Do not work here.

pros: MAWFA offers lots of great benefits, a mostly friendly upbeat environment, and any interaction with Wish Kids, Families, or volunteers is heartwarming.
cons: Very little training was provided despite constant promises to the contrary, number of hours allowed (not salaried) does not allow for amount of work that needs to be completed at the quality it needs to be completed at. Unrealistic standards, and the HQ is very removed from the work with Wish Families which makes Wishes seem trivial as compared to the families' mountains of debts or other long term needs/concerns.

pros: Working for the MAW Foundation is very rewarding and I loved knowing that I was making a difference in the lives of wish kids everyday through my hard work.  It's a small office so it's a pretty tight knit group and everyone works well together.  The hours are pretty flexible and most employees do not stay too late into the evening.
cons: Like many non-profits, the amount of work that employees put in to the Foundation far exceeds the monetary compensation that is received in return.  You really have to love what you're doing.

pros: Great mission and many dedicated team members.
cons: Horrible senior leadership at national office lead by a COO who has no business leading people. Most senior leaders come from American Express and will complain about the culture that they left, only to have brought it with them. The lack of concern for those who are actually trying to support chapters is disturbing. The class system between the “SLT” and the average employee leads to tremendous turnover, especially among experiences hires. Hopefully the new CEO will clean out the AMEX clique and get this place doing what is should be doing. I saw many talented individuals at all levels recognize this quickly. Most experienced hires bail starting at the 6-12 month mark.

review_title: Great Mission, wonderful experience for young professionals
pros:
1. The Mission- the kids and families are what keep people inspired to work here

2. The Company Culture- telecommuting is a valid option here- many National Office staff work remotely, staff are encouraged to take your vacation time, flexible schedules when needed, overall management is very accomodating to staff needs

3. Great Brand- it is exciting to work for such a wonderful organization and you can proudly represent the brand because the mission really is helping families during a diffcult time. Make-A-Wish staff and volunteers operate with a lot of integrity. 

4. Job responsibilities- as a young professional, you are given an opportunity to handle a lot more than you would at a regular corporate job in the for-profit world. There is tons of work and if you are willing to take on projects you can get some great experience.
cons:
1. Tension between National Office and International Office.  Also, sometimes tension between Chapters and National Office, although those problems have started to fade in recent years. Every Make-A-Wish office is its own seperate 501(c)(3), which makes for an "every office for themselves" mentality.  The structure needs to change for cooperation to continue. Leadership can preach the "Power of One" message, but unless the organizational structure changes there will always be the need to take care of your own chapter first before helping others. 

2. Change is slow moving.  People at Make-A-Wish are sometimes afraid to ruffle people's feathers. Everyone wants to be the "nice guy", which causes staff to dance around problems instead of facing them head on. 

3. Promotions are scarce- you have to work at Make-A-Wish a very long time to get promoted to the senior manager, director or VP level.  If you are okay with being an assistant, coordinator or manager forever you'll be happy here. 

4. Salary & Benefits are just okay. Because the promotions are scarce, you don't move past your annual 3% raise each year which can be frustrating. Heath coverage for employee is at no cost, which is great, but if you want to add your spouse or kids to the plan be prepared to pay a premium.  They do offer 401k matching, short term disability, long term disability, etc.

pros:
Wonderful mission with wonderful volunteers
Wish Managers are the heart of the organization
External events based on fun and inspirational stories
Work is easy and rewarding
cons:
Non-diverse team - management hires friends with little experience or skill to fill key roles
Not a good environment for high-performing employees
Management is ego-driven rather than driven by passion for the mission 
Unfair and retaliatory employment practices
Management lacks wisdom and is not trust worthy 
Immature social/ work environment
Inconsiderate co-workers
Lack of team integration
Not an inclusive culture
Work is not challenging

review_title: Outstanding Organization that Cares for its Employees.
pros: Make-A-Wish Illinois provides an amazing opportunity to utilize your professional skills to directly advance a mission that is impacting the lives of children and families who are battling critical illness. Adding to that, Make-A-Wish Illinois invests in my future as an employee. I have been given access to amazing professional development and have been given great growth both in terms of rewards and opportunities. This is a company that truly cares about people.
cons: No downsides! I truly think this is an amazing place to be. Couldn't be happier with my career at this point.

pros: Great mission, new HQ building, passionate staff.   Significant turnover recently signals big changes and isn't necessarily a bad thing, despite what you may read in some of these reviews.  David Williams is a wonderful leader and has had a good run with the organization but his departure will lead to continued evolution of the brand, culture and mission.  Its a good time to join the team and ride the wave of change!
cons: Limited resources, complicated federated model, unique culture that isn't always easy to navigate.

pros: Nothing gets better than the mission of Make-A-Wish! In general, the work is very rewarding, the employees are very nice and smart, and the company culture is relaxed. The CEO is very genuine and humble, which is refreshing.
cons: There are some issues at the SVP level that the CEO, despite his many good qualities, won't address. Turnover is higher than the average nonprofit, likely because of this, but also because compensation isn't especially competitive. Also, if you work at HQ, it's in Phoenix-- it's hard to attract good talent to the area without compensating them for it....

review_title: One of America's most iconic brands is poised for more growth
pros: In my 4+ years at the National Office in Phoenix, I've had the privilege to be part of an exciting cultural and brand transformation. This includes a talented and highly sought after new CEO joining the organization, the establishment of a professional, disciplined strategic project management and data analytics team, the launch of a number of award-winning and highly successful digital campaigns, and a data-driven brand re-positioning and visual refresh . I've particularly  enjoyed the opportunity to interact and learn from Make-A-Wish's Fortune 500 corporate partners and national board members. Being able to network and learn from C-suite executives at companies like Disney, Airbnb, Subaru, Southwest Airlines, TopGolf, Lokai, Mozilla, etc. is an opportunity few jobs offer. Most of all, my interactions with the mission and specifically wish kids and their families has been an experience without peer. It's also been exciting to see the medical community in the U.S. and Europe release new research opening the door to the possibilities that wishes have medical and financial benefits.
cons:
The biggest disadvantages about working for Make-A-Wish is the fact that a majority of Americans incorrectly view it as a last wish or a dying wish only for terminal kids, when in fact for many of the  wish kids, a wish serves as a catalyst to better health. While this is an exciting marketing challenge, the organization is not currently equipped with the resources to adequately address this opportunity. Like most nonprofits, Make-A-Wish currently (December 2018) employs a "do more with less" philosophy, which can be frustrating at times. 

The organization has also been experienced significant culture change over the past four years, due in part to growth and an influx of new employees. Make-A-Wish is still grappling with this change, and is still in the process of determining what kind of culture it wants to embody.

review_title: I thoroughly enjoyed my time working for the Make-A-Wish Foundation.
pros: As an intern with the Make-A-Wish Foundation in Dallas and Fort Worth, I learned a great deal about non-profit "life". I had an incredible experience overall: both offices treated me with respect and courtesy, always had important work for me to accomplish, and took time to write recommendations for me at later dates.
cons: The internships were unpaid, which made it difficult to spend a significant amount of time at the office. I had to balance a second job with my internship.

job_title: Director of Community Development in Fresno, CA
pros: You can have somewhat of a flexible schedule but be prepared to work overtime at a moments notice. This job is project driven.
cons: Not a lot of support from the Board or Executive Director which can make it hard to be competitive for donor dollars in the community. Must be able to work independently with little resources for development. A lot of administrative work with no assistance.

review_title: MAW to Made a Mistake taking this job
job_title: Senior Project Manager in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Location  , underground parking, free coffee and ice cream.
cons: Very poor and delusional leadership in the National Office. Hiring process for Managers and Directors is unbelievably poor for an organization of this size. In some cases, they interviewed only one candidate for Director positions and they were external candidates. Don't believe their "we hire from within" philosophy. Most of the Directors and Executive Leadership Team have come from other companies. not all but some.  If you do decided to roll the dice, I would avoid any position that works directly with the chapters such as Chapter Advancement, Compliance or CFS. If you really want to work with Make a Wish,  I would recommend working for a Chapter

review_title: Metro New York and Western New York Chapter
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: There are a lot of feel good moments knowing you are granting the wish of a very sick child. And the employees generally have hearts of gold. This is one of the best nonprofits in terms of national management in the country.
cons: Not much room to be creative, and consequently not much room for individual growth. Make-A-Wish is very good at what they do and has been for years. This particular office was not interested in hearing new ideas.

job_title: Development Intern in El Paso, TX
pros: Great learning environment, organizational culture, and overall purpose! The Development Director in my office was very invested in helping me learn.
cons: The office space is fairly small.  Additionally, since it is a non-profit, the interns are not receiving any compensation.  If one is looking for a paid summer or semester internship, this would not be the company to apply to.

review_title: Awful place to work full where managment treats employees like garbage
pros: The only pro are the scraps they leave lower level employees after meetings.
cons: Management rule as dictators and berate employees. CEO turns a blind eyes and lets management do what they want. Very high turnover because employees finally get tired and realize that even though the mission is wonderful, the treatment by management isn't worth it. David Williams turns a blind eye and doesn't care or do anything. He only protects Executive Management and Directors. By far the two worst areas to work are Compliance and Chapter Advancement. If you decide to roll the dice, Information Technology and Business Operations are the only two areas that are decent. Avoid, avoid, avoid. Notice they are constantly hiring. There is a reason for that.

pros: In Pittsburgh, the MAW office there has a great team in place, fabulous office, excellent CEO, friendly staff and free beverages! It was an absolute joy going to work everyday and gave me unique insight into how a non-profit works. Everybody there was helpful (don't hesitate to ask questions) and approachable. Little (to none) in-house politics or cattiness.
cons: I mean, it is a non-profit so the pay isn't great and the chance for advancement is little to none since turn over is non existent.

pros: Great mission, non-leadership employees mean well for the most part
cons: Leadership is nonexistent, new ideas and viewpoints are shot down, employees disciplined for speaking up (including when managers and above have crossed the line and been inappropriate with staff), must share hotel rooms with staff members - even your Manager/Director. EXTREMELY high turnover rate. There are no opportunities for growth in your career or for personal development. You'll be pressured to give not only your time and sanity, but also through your paycheck because leadership "wants to be able to say that 100% of staff gives back to the organization".

job_title: Volunteer Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: The Organization does amazing things.  I was proud to be a member of their organization.  The office I was in had wonderful people working there.
cons:
Wish Coordinators are expected to work very long hours and have case loads like social workers.
The office I worked in wasn't fair regarding promotions.  If you were liked you got promoted, if not, then you weren't promoted.

pros: I loved working as an intern at Make-A-Wish. I was always busy doing things that actually benefitted the company rather than chores that are intern stereotypes. The brand advancement team was helpful, funny and never afraid to give you feedback. Make-A-Wish also provides intern activities that foster interpersonal connections, lunch with the CEO and plenty of networking opportunities. They're open to new ideas that could be implemented and treat interns as full-time employees rather than disposable staff.
cons: Sometimes the office was boiling hot, others freezing cold. Some of the software should be updated; it feels like some of it is from 2005.

pros: Extraordinary mission, vision and values. Well managed organization with committed, caring people. Supportive, effective working board of directors. Employee-driven culture. Having a singular mission (to grant wishes) creates a rallying point for a staff of varying backgrounds, and reduces mission uncertainty/mission creep. Well-funded programs allow for creative mission fulfillment and employee retention. The Arizona chapter is the founding chapter of the organization, which means tremendous pride in the "flagship" status. The office being in the same region as Make-A-Wish America (the organization's corporate HQ) means easy access to top decision makers and opportunities for closer partnerships and pilot programs.
cons:
Some stasis on the executive team, the downside of low turnover. The CEO is retirement age, but having turned the chapter around from under performing to top performing in her tenure, she rests on her laurels. While the staff is empowered to innovate and bolster the culture, the CEO sits in her office and plays on her iPad and asks donors and board members for personal favors. It's this former employee's opinion that all favors should be reserved to support wish granting programs, not the CEO's family and personal life. There is a bit of a "mean girl" culture in the C-Suite, with the Chief Development Officer and CEO often in personal conflict that can be felt throughout the office.  

There is a culture of body and food shaming, an unfortunate reality at an organization dedicated to serving ill children. The CDO has been heard making multitudes of comments about employees' body shapes and sizes as well as work apparel and diet. It can feel quite hostile and personal.

There's tension among the generations, with some Baby Boomer aged people openly making negative and stereotype-based comments about Millenial aged staff members, specifically on the fundraising team. Young talent has turned over because of the perceived pressure to "stay in line" and not show initiative or ambition, which are read as threats by older staff.

pros: The mission is undeniably great.  Tt is a chance to work with children and families.  Lots of support from the Central office.
cons: Chapters are ruled by CEOs who often have a limited grasp of fundraising.  If you are a serious fund raiser, you may get tired of the disrespectful attitude toward fundraising, cronyism, and lack of performance metrics.

review_title: Inspiring Mission and Amazing People! (National Office)
job_title: Senior Project Manager in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
* Stellar Leadership: From the Director level all the way up through the CEO, the leadership at Make-A-Wish is empowering, supportive and inspiring. We are in an amazing period of growth and change (challenging the status quo) and because of the leadership, we feel empowered as staff to be part of that change.

* The People: Every single person I work with is dedicated to the mission, assumes best intent of their fellow staff member (making a culture of collaboration and support),  and provides extremely high quality of work. They also are genuinely nice and caring about each other as people. This may sound like a small thing, but it's so refreshing and makes it feel even more like we are one big team, working together to achieve the same goals and vision. 

* The Mission: It's so nice at the end of the day to be part of a mission to grant wishes - bringing hope and joy to our wish kids and their families. I hear at least one story a day that makes me beam with pride that I get to be even a small part of that.

* Education Opportunities: Our HR and Strategy teams are dedicated to ensuring that our staff get the ability to train on process, communication and leadership. I have grown so much as a staff member because of this - it's invaluable! I have earned my LEAN Six Sigma yellow and green belts, gotten to take several leadership classes on leading my staff and being a self-leader (meaning that we all are leaders, even if we don't manage staff). We also have had sessions on "fierce communications," walking us through working better together (including having tough conversations when we need to) through better communication.

* Work/Life Balance: For most roles in the organization, there is incredible work/life balance. Some roles do require hours outside of the traditional 8-5 day, but that's true anywhere. More so than any other place I have worked, people respect your personal time and your vacation time.
cons: * Upward Movement: The only con is that there is no guarantee of upward movement within the organization and it can take a long time to happen, but I feel this is true of most organizations. I have seen in more recent years many more internal promotions and giving staff the opportunity to take on more responsibilities, but for someone looking for a fast track to promotions, this may not be the organization for you. I find great joy in the regular challenges I get to take on and have been promoted since I started but it just can't be an assumption. Those that are good with challenging themselves to do more and strive higher without the necessary guarantee of a title/salary promotion will thrive here.

pros: Love the mission and the wish kiddos.

No confidentiality, management has loose lips.  They put current employees thru interview process for different job knowing they won't get it because the job and pay has already been given to someone else.  This is common practice at MAW OH, KY & IN.
